title: Virginia Ham
ingredients: 3 tablespoons dry sherry; or, sweet-pickle vinegar
instructions: The ham was cured for at least 12 months –
Scrub the ham to remove the coating of seasonings and place in a container large enough to cover it with water.  Soak the ham for 24 hours, changing the water often.

In a large covered roasting pan, place the ham, skin side down with enough fresh water to cover.  Bring the water to a boil then reduce the heat to keep the ham, covered, at a bare simmer for 20 to 25 minutes per pound.  When cooked, based on the ham’s weight, remove the ham from the water and set it on a cutting board.  When it has cooled enough for you to work with it trim off the skin; then working carefully, trim off any excessive fat.  Make sure that a layer of fat remains for you to score and prepare for baking.
In a small bowl combine the brown sugar, the bread crumbs, and the ground cloves.  In a separate small container mix the honey and sherry (or sweet-pickle vinegar) and set aside.

Score the remaining fat on the ham; cutting into the fat with a sharp knife in opposite direction diagonal cuts, creating a diamond pattern.  Place the ham in a shallow baking pan and press the brown sugar mixture into the ham.
Place the ham in the center rack of the preheated oven and bake it, uncovered, for 15 minutes; or, until the brown sugar has melted.
Remove the ham from the oven and drizzle the honey/sherry (or sweet-pickle vinegar) uniformly over the ham.  Return the ham to the oven for an additional 15 minutes.
The ham was cured less then 12 months –
If the ham was cured less then 12 months then simply follow the instructions on the wrapper or hang the ham in a dry cool place and allow it to age further.

Source:  The Colonial Williamsburg Tavern Cookbook, by The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, Recipes Developed by John R. Gonzales, Edited by Charles Pierce, Clarkson Potter/Publishers, New York, © 2001 by The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation.
